msContents.summary: Recto (unpublished): remains of list (partly faded out) with numbers added in a different hand. Verso: Letter of Arsinoos who asks his 'brother' Alkimos for an agricultural (?) instrument and tells him that he has dispatched clothes and fruit; in a postscript he asks for some more things.

condition.ab: Text on the recto cut off at left and right side, so that verso could be reused for a letter (verso text upside down with respect to the recto); seen from the verso, the papyrus is complete, apart from some holes and part of the right margin

layout.ab: Recto ca. 35 lines along the fibers with later additional notes; verso 30 lines across the fibers
The letter published as P. Warren 15 is written on the verso

listBibl.bibl: M. David - B.A. van Groningen - J.C. van Oven, The Warren Papyri (P. Warren) (Papyrologica Lugduno-Batava 1, Leiden 1941), p. 44-45 = P.Warren 15, also cited as P.L.Bat. I 15

div.ab: (Translation from P.L.Bat. I 15) Arsinoos to his dear Alkimos greeting. By all means take care that the roll shall be given to the man whom I send, on account of its absolute necessity; do it at all events. I have dispatched to you, my brother, through the camel-driver Horion 1 pair of tunics; but during my absence the weaver has made them without border. As you have ordered, I have also made ready the purple cloth. Accept from the donkey-driver 1 artaba of dates and 70 lemons. If you want more dates, tell me at which price I may(?). I wish you good health, my dear. Take care that two measures of dry coriander-seed shall be made ready and keep them at yours till I come along on the 25th. There is at the tanner's a cow-hiide given to him by Hierax, the man from the sandy district(?). Take care that this also shall be given to the donkey-driver. If not, at any rate 3 --- of cow-hides(?). But do your best, my brother.
